Column Comment.0: SUPPORT FACILITY SUBTYPE: check constraint value that is used to maintain therelationship between SUPPORT FACILITY and its various sub-types. In this table,may only be SF_ROAD.
Column Comment.1: SUPPORT FACILITY IDENTIFIER: Unique identifier for the support facility. A supportfacility provides operational support for activities. These facilities may include roads,transmission towers, airstrips, vessels, docks and so on. Sub tyes are used tomaintain integration with the rest of the model.
Column Comment.2: ACTIVE INDICATOR: A Y/N flag indicating whether this row of data is currently eitheractive / valid (Y) or inactive / invalid (N).
Column Comment.3: ROAD CAPACITY: The weight capacity of the road.
Column Comment.5: COMMUNICATION FREQUENCY: the frequency to be used for comunication,expressed in MHz. Units of measure are not provided, as the frequuencies arealways in MHz.
Column Comment.6: COMMUNICATION FREQUENCY DESCRIPTION: a short narrative description ofthe communication frequency, such as where it should be obtained from or how toget it. In some cases, the communcation frequency may be provided as well.
Column Comment.7: ROAD CONTROL TYPE: The type of controls in place to access a road, such asradio controls for well site access roads. Often, this is done for safety reasons.
Column Comment.8: CURRENT OPERATOR BUSINESS ASSOCIATE IDENTIFIER: Unique identifier forthe business associate who currently operates this road. Note that historic tracking ofoperatorship cannot be tracked here, but if you need the information you can use thetable SF COMPONENT to track some history information.
Column Comment.9: DIRECTION: the general or listed direction of this road.
Column Comment.10: ROAD DRIVING DIRECTION: Indicates the side of the road that you drive on, eitherleft (Canada, US, Europe) or right (UK, Australia, Japan).
Column Comment.11: EFFECTIVE DATE: The date that the data in this row first came into effect.
Column Comment.12: EXPIRY DATE: The date that the data in this row was no longer active or in effect.
Column Comment.13: ROW_MANAGEMENT_GUID: This value may be used to provide a global uniqueidentifier for this row of data. Use of this column is not mandatory, but if used,optional PPDM NOT NULL and UNIQUE INDEX constraints provided in the datamodel DDL should be created.
Column Comment.14: REMARK: Narrative remarks relating to this row of data.
Column Comment.15: ROAD LENGTH: The length of the road or portion of the road that is tracked.
Column Comment.17: ROAD TYPE: A valid type of road, such as public, logging, private etc.
Column Comment.18: ROAD WIDTH: the width of the road or portion of the road.
Column Comment.20: SOURCE: The individual, company, state, or government agency designated as thesource of information for this row.
Column Comment.21: SURFACE TYPE: A valid list of surface types for various support facility. May includeconcrete, asphalt, dirt, gravel, sand etc.
Column Comment.22: ROAD TRAFFIC FLOW TYPE: The type of traffic flow for a road, usually one way,two way or reversible (traffic flow changes during the day or based on some otherbusiness rule).
Column Comment.23: ROW CHANGED BY: Application login id of the user who last changed the row.
Column Comment.24: ROW CHANGED DATE: System date of the last time the row was changed.
Column Comment.25: ROW CREATED BY: System user who created this row of data.
Column Comment.26: ROW CREATED DATE: Date that the row was created on.
Column Comment.27: ROW_EFFECTIVE_DATE: A system assigned date that specified when a row of datais effective from a systems perspective. This may be the date that a row of data wasmade available to end users, for example.
Column Comment.28: ROW_EXPIRY_DATE: A system assigned date that specified when a row of data isno longer effective from a systems perspective. This may be the date that a row ofdata was no longer available to end users, for example.
Column Comment.29: PPDM ROW QUALITY: A set of values indicating the quality of data in this row,usually with reference to the method or procedures used to load the data, althoughother types of quality reference are permitted.
